The French New Wave, a cinematic movement that emerged in the late 1950s and early 1960s, dramatically influenced editing techniques, bringing a fresh, radical approach to film narrative and style. Pioneers like François Truffaut and Jean-Luc Godard broke away from the classical Hollywood continuity editing, favoring jump cuts, discontinuous shots, and visible editing transitions. These techniques were employed not only to create a sense of realism and spontaneity but also to invite the audience into a more active viewing experience by making them aware of the constructed nature of film. The movement's emphasis on personal expression and innovative storytelling paved the way for a new generation of filmmakers who sought to experiment beyond traditional narrative structures.
